problem.tex: State Cauchy's theorem on simply connected regions. Prove that any holomorphic function on a simply connected region admits an antiderivative.

solution.tex: Let $G$ be a simply connected region and let $f:G\to\mathbb{C}$ be holomorphic. Cauchy's theorem states that for all closed piecewise smooth paths $\gamma:[a,b]\to G$, \[\int_\gamma f(z)dz=0.\] We will use this to construct an antiderivative of $f$. Fix a point $x\in G$. For arbitrary $z\in G$ let $p_z$ denote a piecewise smooth path in $G$ starting at $x$ and ending at $z$. Define $F$ by \[F(z)=\int_{p_z}f(w)dw.\] We need to check that this is well-defined. Suppose $p_z,p'_z$ are two paths in $G$ starting at $x$ and ending at $z$. Then the concatenation $\gamma$ of $p_z$ with the reverse of $p'_z$ is a loop in $G$, so by Cauchy's integral theorem \[\int_{p_z}f(w)dw-\int_{p'_z}f(w)dw=\int_\gamma f(w)dw=0.\] Thus $F$ is well-defined. $F$ is an antiderivative by construction but a detailed reasoning is given in the proof of Morera's theorem.
